utterances: (Laughter) You got that pretty fast, sir.

Story, order, range.
It can't be tall because that's only four letters.
Yeah, what's the opposite of that?
Short, short, short.
There you go - short story, short order, short range.
How about sauce, S-A-U-C-E, cider, C-I-D-E-R, and store.
Oh, that's going to be apple.
Apple as in Apple Store.

Ed Roberts of Spring Prairie, Texas, thanks for playing The Puzzle.
Hey, thank you.
All right, Will, what is the challenge for next week?
Yeah, it comes from listener Mark Maravetz of Albuquerque, N.M.
Take five consecutive letters of the alphabet.
Write them in left to right order.
Insert five letters at certain spots - and these will all go between the first and last given letters - and the result will be a famous actor, first and last names.
Who is it?
So again five consecutive letters of the alphabet in left to right order.
Insert five letters at certain spots to name a famous actor.
Who is it?
When you have the answer, go to our website, npr.org/puzzle, and click on the Submit Your Answer link.
Just one entry per person, please.

(SOUNDBITE OF MUSIC)
This is TALK OF THE NATION.
I'm Neal Conan, in Washington.
The unemployment rate last month fell to 8.8 percent, the lowest level in two years, and McDonald's announced a plan to hire 50,000 workers as part of a national hiring day.

Yet amid the good news, economists continue to warn the recovery remains fragile, that different parts of the country do better than others, and that something close to a full recovery is probably at least a couple of years away.
Still, some things have changed.
Employers, what's different?
And workers, what's changed where you live?
Tell us your story: 800-989-8255 is the phone number.
Email us: talk@npr.org.
You can also join the conversation on our website.
That's at npr.org.
Click on TALK OF THE NATION.
Later in the program, another international intervention in Africa, in Ivory Coast this time, where the U.N.
and France attacked troops on one side of a civil war yesterday.
But first, Art Hicks joins us from his office in New Jersey, where he's the president of Cybex International, a company that makes treadmills, bikes and other exercise equipment for health clubs.
And it's nice to have you with us today.
Thanks, Neal.
Glad to be with you.
And we have heard in a recent report - some people may have heard on ALL THINGS CONSIDERED - you're doing rather better.
Yes.
I would say in the middle of 2010, we saw bottom of our sales, and it's increased since then.
In the fourth quarter of 2010, sales were up about 15 percent, and they've continued in the first quarter.
Or it will be up more than 10 percent in the first quarter.
And is that as a result of domestic consumption, or how much are you shipping overseas?
Well, I tell my board it's obviously shrewd management.
(Soundbite of laughter)
But actually, it's a mix.
I would tell your board that, too.
Yeah.
Sometimes they believe me, sometimes they don't.
But we sell in 90 countries.
Almost a third of our sales come from outside North America.
And both North America and international markets are doing fairly well.
And have you shifted - when things start getting better, companies typically start hiring temp workers until they can be sure that this is going to be something permanent.
Yeah, we have a great employee base, well-trained, and the first reaction is that we authorize overtime.
We increase that to what we think is a reasonable level, maybe 50 hours per week, and then we add a temporary workforce.
And then after we believe the sales levels have been sustained, then we would convert those temps to full-time employees.
It's a good thing at this point.
And how many new, full-time employees have you brought on in the last...
Well, we're up about six employees since the end of the year.
We have about 600 employees.
Around 60 percent remain involved in production.
So this is - six doesn't sound like a lot, but it's nevertheless pretty significant.
It really is.
And we're a somewhat seasonal business.
June, July, August are slow periods.
So I wouldn't expect to hire more production folks until fourth quarter.
But we've already made some important investments in areas that we think will drive sales.
For example, we hired recently a VP of marketing.
We're looking for a Web designer.
We hired a West Coast sales manager.
We're looking for a design engineer for (unintelligible) group.
And I've seen your products in too many hotel exercise rooms to count.
I hope you're staying healthy with us.
Well, thank you, but I'll do my best.
But in any case, I know you've been in business a while.
The number of workers you've added, does it compare to the number of workers that you may have dropped when things weren't so good?
